contextId.information: This sentence uses a double negative to create emphasis of the positive equivalent. AT: "A prophet is always honored, except" or "The only place a prophet is not honored is" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublenegatives]])
contextId.quote: A prophet is not without honor, except

contextId.information: The words "cannot" and "except" are both negative words. In some languages it is more natural to use a positive statement. AT: "This kind can be cast out only by prayer" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublenegatives]])
contextId.quote: This kind cannot be cast out except by prayer

contextId.information: This can be stated positively. AT: "Everyone who has left ... will receive" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublenegatives]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_litotes]])
contextId.quote: there is no one who has left ... who will not receive

contextId.information: Here "not doubt" is a double negative meaning "truly believe." Jesus says it both ways for emphasis. AT: "if he truly believes in his heart" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublenegatives]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: if he does not doubt in his heart but believes
